item.title: HTTP/2, RFC 7540
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: HTTP/2 is official, with RFC 7540. Alongside RFC 7541, HPACK: Header Compression for HTTP/2. Worth reading these related posts: HTTP/2 is Done by Mark Nottingham ( chair of the IETF HTTP Working Group ) and RFC 7540 is HTTP/2 from Daniel Stenberg ( author of cURL ).
item.content:encoded:
HTTP/2 is official, with RFC 7540. Alongside RFC 7541, HPACK: Header Compression for HTTP/2.

Worth reading these related posts: HTTP/2 is Done by Mark Nottingham ( chair of the IETF HTTP Working Group ) and RFC 7540 is HTTP/2 from Daniel Stenberg ( author of cURL ).

item.title: TCP Over HTTP, A.K.A. HTTP 2.0
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Skimming through the HTTP 2.0 draft RFC that was posted yesterday I’m left with the distinct feeling of implementing TCP on top of HTTP: I’m in the camp that believes that future versions of HTTP should continue to be a text based protocol ( with compression support ). Most weeks I look at several raw […]
item.content:encoded:
Skimming through the HTTP 2.0 draft RFC that was posted yesterday I’m left with the distinct feeling of implementing TCP on top of HTTP:

I’m in the camp that believes that future versions of HTTP should continue to be a text based protocol ( with compression support ).

Most weeks I look at several raw HTTP requests and responses. Yes, there will still be tools like cURL ( which I love ) to dig into HTTP transactions, so it isn’t the end of the world. Still, I am sad to see something that is currently fairly easy to follow turn into something significantly more complex.
